USS Essex CV-9 is the lead ship of the Essex-class aircraft carriers of the United States Navy. It is the fourth U.S. military ship to bear the name Essex, commemorating the donation of the first Essex ship to the U.S. government by residents of Essex County, Massachusetts, in 1799. Because of its outstanding performance in World War II, the ship's sailors called it "Fightin'est Ship in the Fleet".

Construction of the USS Essex CV-9 began on 28 April 1941 at the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company. A few months after the attack on Pearl Harbor, the United States officially entered World War II and accelerated the construction of several aircraft carriers, including the USS Essex CV-9.USS Essex CV-9 was launched on 31 July 1942 and began participating in the Pacific War in 1943. After the war, USS Essex CV-9 was mothballed and modernized. In 1951 , USS Essex CV-9 was recommissioned after a refit and participated in two Korean War cruises, during which the USS Essex was redesignated as an attack carrier and the hull number was changed to CVA-9. After the Korean War, USS Essex CVA-9 was again refitted with an angled deck and transferred to the Atlantic Fleet. In 1960, USS Essex CV-9 was redesignated as an anti-submarine aircraft carrier and changed its hull designation to CVS-9. In addition to major wars, USS Essex CVS-9 was involved in several Cold War crises, including the Bay of Pigs incident and the Cuban Missile Crisis. Interestingly,USS Essex CVS-9 also participated in the U.S. space program, recovering the command module of Apollo 7.

USS Essex CVS-9 was decommissioned on 30 June 1969 and joined the reserve fleet. On June 1, 1973, USS Essex CVS-9 was decommissioned and sold for dismantling for $1,660,000. On June 1, 1975, USS Essex CVS-9 was dismantled in the town of Carney, New Jersey.
USS Essex CV-9 received a Presidential Commendation and 13 Battle Stars in World War II.

The Essex-class aircraft carrier is a type of fleet aircraft carrier built by the United States Navy during World War II, with 24 ships of the same type, divided into "short hull type" and "long hull type", the difference is in the bow. Of these, 17 were built during World War II and 7 after the war. It was originally planned to build 32 ships, of which 6 were cancelled and 2 were not built. It is the largest number of first-class aircraft carriers ever built by the United States, and became the mainstay of the US Navy in the Pacific War, telling the world the importance of the struggle for air supremacy in modern warfare.

Prior to the Essex class, the U.S. Navy had built two Yorktown-class aircraft carriers and USS Wasp CV-7 within the framework of the 1922 Washington Naval Treaty. With Japan's withdrawal from the Second London Naval Conference in January 1936, the new treaty came to naught. President Roosevelt was determined to double down on naval expansion to balance Japan. Promoted by Chairman of the Navy Council Carl Vinson, Congress passed the Second Vinson Act on May 17, 1938, expanding the size of the Navy by two percent while increasing the tonnage of aircraft carriers by 40,000 tons. Although the Yorktown class had problems such as insufficient aircraft capacity, the U.S. military used 20,000 tons to build the Hornet to solve the urgent problem, while the other 20,000 tons were used to build the improved Yorktown-class aircraft carrier, designated CV-9, or Essex class.

The Essex-class aircraft carrier, as the successor to the Yorktown-class aircraft carrier, its improvements are mainly aimed at the shortcomings of the Yorktown-class. Especially in the face of the problem that the hangar and deck of the new carrier-based aircraft are stretched, in addition, it is necessary to strengthen the catapult, interceptor cable, interception net, lifting platform, etc. At the same time, the Navy also requires that the new aircraft carrier must strengthen anti-aircraft fire and defense, while maintaining high speed. Neither the 20,000 tonnes authorized by the Vincennes Act nor the 23,000 tonnes limited by the treaty are sufficient for application. After the outbreak of World War II , the naval treaty was immediately invalid, and the Essex class design was no longer limited in tonnage, and the United States accelerated the design process. In 1940, the standard displacement of the finalized Essex class reached 27,500 tons.

In June 1940, with the strong support of President Roosevelt, the U.S. Congress passed the Fleet Expansion Act and the Two Oceans Navy Act, which planned to build 11 aircraft carriers in fiscal 1940 and 2 Essex-class aircraft carriers in fiscal 1941. On April 28, 1941, the construction of the lead ship of the Essex-class aircraft carrier, the USS Essex CV-9, began.

The F2H Banshee is a single-seat carrier-based fighter/reconnaissance aircraft developed by MacDonald and modified from the FH-1 Phantom. On August 25, 1951, USS Essex CV-9 became the first aircraft carrier in the U.S. Navy to carry the jet F2H Banshee on combat duty, successfully completing the first takeoff and landing of a jet aircraft on an aircraft carrier in actual combat.
